Award.AwardTitle: SEP Collaborative: Integrating Heterogeneous Energy Resources for Sustainable Power Networks - A Systems Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF Sustainable Energy pathways (SEP) Program, under the umbrella of the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability (SEES) initiative, will support the research program of Prof. Dennice Gayme and co-workers at Johns Hopkins University, Prof. Aranya Chakrabortty and co-workers at North Carolina State University, and Prof. Judith cardell and co-workers at Smith College to develop a method to integrate heterogeneous energy resources to form sustainable power networks. The objective of this program is to examine how the control and design of large-scale and distributed energy resources can facilitate the grid-integration of large amounts of renewable energy. Wind energy is used as a representative, heterogeneous and variable renewable energy source to address the following three fundamental challenges: (I) the need to manage stability, (II) the need to cost effectively maintain reliable operation, and (III) the need to reflect stability and operational criteria in markets and policy. Models of the power grid, such as continuum representations (partial differential equations that directly support combined spatial and temporal analysis) and network power flows that include storage and demand-side management, will be developed and used to address stability, control, reliability, and performance/efficiency questions. As input for these continuum and power flow models, the project will utilize outputs from fluid dynamics ("Large-Eddy") simulations that model unsteady wind farm and atmospheric boundary layer interactions and have been validated using laboratory and field observations. Analysis using the grid level models will both inform and be shaped by the design of new regulatory and economic reforms that will enable renewable resource purveyors to participate in power markets. Connections between operational and market issues such as power flow regulation, grid operation and risk mitigation strategies using storage and demand-side management will be made by leveraging tools based on optimization, convex relaxations and optimal control theory, which are common to the economics and controls communities.

This project will facilitate a more sustainable power system through its technical contributions, education, training and mentorship. Research topics will form the basis for student projects in new sustainable energy related curricula at all three participating institutions. Summer undergraduate research opportunities will provide students with skills for participating in sustainable energy research and future employment in related industries. This program will directly facilitate NSF's STEM related goals through JHU's participation in the NSF-funded Center for Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning (CIRTL), the Science House partnership between NCSU and local K-12 teachers, and the involvement of the only all-women engineering program in the US (Smith College). At JHU this project will operate under the aegis of E2SHI, which promotes cross-disciplinary research, outreach, and education for critical environmental, energy and sustainability issues. E2SHI is committed to systems-level integrated research and outreach for sustainability.

The tools to be developed will help facilitate the transformation of our current fossil fuel based power system to one that is safe, reliable and efficient without compromising energy security or exhausting resources needed for future generations. The project's results will be directly relevant to the electric power industry and its regulators as they are faced with the challenges of incorporating larger fractions of highly heterogeneous renewable resources, such as wind energy, into the grid. Specifically, the results will provide system operators with better representations of the impacts of renewables, and better control tools to mitigate those impacts; planners and investors with a framework for evaluating optimal resource allocation; and policy makers with a systematic means of investigating how new regulations and market rules can incent effective deployment of these tools and resources. Complementary educational programs and mentorship will develop researchers and practitioners with the skills required to create and advance this sustainable energy future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined how control and design of large-scale and distributed energy resources can facilitate integration of large amounts of renewable energy into the electric power grid. Wind was used as a representative, heterogeneous and variable renewable energy source. The research took a system theoretic end-to-end approach starting with the development of better ways to characterize wind farm power output then moving into evaluation and mitigation of the effect of wind power on grid stability, operation and design; and finally evaluation and design of new energy markets in order to better grid integrate wind energy and related resources. The coordination of experts in fluid mechanics (wind farms), control theory, power system optimization and market design enabled analysis of technical and physical system challenges as well as the synthesis of these issues into recommendations for associated regulatory, policy and market reforms. 

Intellectual Merit: Many previous approaches to power system analysis have been discipline specific.  As a consequence, solutions in one area, e.g., wind farm design, have not been well tied to power system and operational questions.  This work combined basic research in four areas (source characterization, power system stability analysis and control, power systems design and optimization, and the design of market incentives and policy) into integrated approaches to enable greater levels of wind energy integration. Improved simulation tools, particularly large eddy simulation (LES) tools for wind farm flow physics, included the development and further characterization of advanced turbine models. Stability analysis included understanding the effect of wind injection location on the system over long distances as well as the understanding of how these changes affect the underlying system dynamics.  Distributed control design to mitigate these effects took into account knowledge of the wind farm flow physics in terms of the both the inlet and deep array effects due to the turbine arrangements. Our operational analysis included new models for storage citing and dispatch decisions that demonstrated the need to augment current market tools (that are lossless or use less accurate loss factors) in order to make better storage siting decisions. That work also led to some important observations about trade-offs in using energy storage for VAr support (which vastly improves efficiency and reliability of the grid) and the lack of market incentives for storage to provide this valuable service.  The market design work evaluated so-called "ramp capability" or "flexiramp" product in electricity markets, which directly informed the design of such a market in California through PI involvement in the CAISO.  We also used market equilibrium models to simulate how wind uncertainty can be efficiently accommodated in two-settlement markets by financial participants and owners of slow-start assets, even though the first of the two market settlements is executed by the market operator as if it knows what demand and wind will occur in real time

One example of integration across the four areas was the design of a new wind farm model and associated control strategy that enables wind farms to provide critical grid services, see figure 1.  In particular, we demonstrated a model-based receding horizon control approach for wind farms to provide frequency regulation; a grid service that is closely tied to short-term imbalances in active power generation and load.  An example of wind farm power tracking the regulation signal from PJM (the independent system operator in the mid-Atlantic region) is shown in figure 2. 

Broader Impacts:  This research took an integrated approach to improving our ability to integrate wind in the US power system, taking into account multiple aspects of the problem from source characterization and grid operations to the energy markets these resources operate within. This interdisciplinary approach centered on collaboration between fluid dynamists, power system engineers and economists, which led to improved understanding of the broad range of data, analysis, tools and techniques needed to address wind integration.  Students and postdoctoral scholars, in particular, gained exposure to all facets of the problem leading to a better understanding of how their individual research affects the overall system. For example, the students working on source characterization benefited from direct interactions with students working on grid level and economic models. Analysis of new market mechanisms for wind integration was also greatly improved from the improved understanding of wind farm dynamics provided through the fluid dynamics research. 

The project led to a total of 31 published journal papers (10 more are accepted or in press), and 15 conference papers. There were 75 invited presentations associated with the work including several invited workshop and plenary talks. The project partially supported 8 Ph.D. students, 2 Master’s students, and two postdoctoral scholars, contributing to 4 completed Ph.D. dissertations and 2 Master's theses. K-12 outreach included lectures at local high schools and yearly lectures at the Engineering Innovation; a STEM summer program for high school students at JHU.
